Manual installation

Source: vignettes/manual-installation.Rmd
manual-installation.Rmd

Installation

Apart from precommit::use_precommit(), you can install pre-commit manually as described in the official documentation (do not close the log of this process, you might need it later!). Then, you must make sure R finds the executable. To check that, start a new R session after the installation process of pre-commit succeeded and run this command:

precommit::path_pre_commit_exec()
#> "/usr/local/bin/pre-commit"

If it shows a path (like above), you are all set. Skip the rest of this paragraph and go to Configuration. If not, you must manually link the executable.Set the R option precommit.executable to the path where the pre-commit executable lives. Note that the PATH variable that was used in the above command to find the executable might be different in your R session from what you have in your shell, so you can try your luck there:

$where pre-commit
# should give /bin/pre-commit or similar

If this returns a path, set the R option to it, preferrably in your .Rprofile to make sure it is set in a new R session too.

options(precommit.executable = "/path/to/pre-commit")

Now, proceed in the below section on Configuration. If $where pre-commit did not give you a path either, you need to go back to the installation method you used and figure out where the executable got placed. This depends on the installation method and oerating system, so it’s hard for us to give general advice. You may use a Google search like where does pip install executable on Ubuntu? to find the path to the executable.

We are working towards making precommit::path_pre_commit_exec() finding executables automatically with any operating system and installation method, so please open up an issue on GitHub and tell us your installation method, platform and the location of the executable so we can adapt the search heuristic of precommit::path_pre_commit_exec().

If you can’t get it righ, you can still install via conda, where linking the executable is not required.

Configuration

If you’ve installed pre-commit, you can add it to a specific project by adding a .pre-commit-config.yaml file that has a structure like this:

```r tags <- names(git2r::tags(“.”)) latest_tag <- paste0(“v”, max(as.numeric_version(gsub(“^v”, "", tags))))

string <- paste0(“yaml repos: - repo: https://github.com/lorenzwalthert/precommit rev: ", latest_tag , " hooks: - id: style-files - id: parsable-R - id: no-browser-statement - id: readme-rmd-rendered # - id: roxygenize # for repos that are a package. # - id: use-tidy-description # for repos that are a package. # - id: deps-in-desc # for repos that are a package. - id: lintr”) cat(string) ```

repos:
-   repo: https://github.com/lorenzwalthert/precommit
    rev: v0.0.0.9027
    hooks: 
    -   id: style-files
    -   id: parsable-R
    -   id: no-browser-statement
    -   id: readme-rmd-rendered
    # -   id: roxygenize            # for repos that are a package.
    # -   id: use-tidy-description  # for repos that are a package.
    # -   id: deps-in-desc          # for repos that are a package.
    -   id: lintr

The repo key points to the place where the source code of the hooks are stored, not the repo you want to apply them to.

Some hooks also take arguments, see vignette("hook-arguments").

If you want to see the file .pre-commit-config.yaml in RStudio, you have to enable “Show Hidden Files” in the Files Pane of RStudio under More.

Next, run pre-commit install in your repo and you are done.
